segments.key_quote: Narada Muni is inevitably associated with the narrations of the Puranas.
segments.summary: The speaker begins to explain the biographies of some of the sages mentioned in the verses, starting with Narada Muni and his role in the disciplic succession.
segments.transcript: It is a long list of so many names of sages. Sages, Rishis, all varieties of Rishis, Deva Rishis, Brahma Rishis, and Raja Rishis. So Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport a brief biography of some of the sages. Narada Muni Narada Muni is inevitably associated with the narrations of the Puranas. He is described in the Bhagavatam. In his previous life, he was the son of a maidservant. But by good association with pure devotees, he became enlightened in devotional service. And in the next life, he became a perfect man, comparable with himself only. In the Mahabharata, his name is mentioned in many places. He is the principal Deva Rishi, or the chief sage, amongst the demigods. He is the son and disciple of Brahma ji. And from him, the disciplic succession in the line of Brahma has been spread. He initiated Prahlad Maharaj, Dhruva Maharaj, and many celebrated devotees of the Lord. He initiated even Vyasa Deva, the author of Vedic literatures. He initiated Vyasa Deva, the author of Vedic literatures. And from Vyasa Deva, Madhvacharya was initiated. And thus, the Madhva Sampradaya, in which the Gaudiya Sampradaya is also included, has spread all over the universe.
